results.title: Magic lantern slides
results.brief_description: Magic lantern slides are as varied as they are enchanting. While early slides featured line etchings on glass plates, lanternists were soon hand-painting them to give projections vibrancy and depth. When photography arrived in the 1840s, photos started appearing on lantern slides.

constellations_primary.name: Space, sci-fi and cinema fakes
constellations_primary.description: Magic lantern slides were used to entertain and educate audiences in home, theatres and universities. While performers told jokes and fairytales, travelling showmen unveiled exotic locations and scientists revealed the latest discoveries.

results.description:
Magic lantern slides are as varied as they are enchanting. While early slides featured line etchings on glass plates, lanternists were soon hand-painting them to give projections vibrancy and depth.

In the 1820s, copperplate printing processes allowed an image to be stamped on glass. This led to mass slide production from the mid-1800s to the 1920s – particularly of toy slides, which were printed with decals and bordered with colourful edges to protect children’s hands.

The arrival of photography in the 1840s advanced things: photos printed on glass brought real-life scenes to life. But technology didn’t diminish the craftsmanship of lanternists, who still retouched worn slides by hand.
description_for_label:
Magic lantern slides are as varied as they are enchanting. While early slides featured line etchings on glass plates, lanternists were soon hand-painting them to give projections vibrancy and depth.

In the 1820s, copperplate printing processes allowed an image to be stamped on glass. This led to mass slide production from the mid-1800s to the 1920s – particularly of toy slides, which were printed with decals and bordered with colourful edges to protect children’s hands.

The arrival of photography in the 1840s advanced things: photos printed on glass brought real-life scenes to life. But technology didn’t diminish the craftsmanship of lanternists, who still retouched worn slides by hand.

results.title: The Dark Current
results.credit_line:
Ian Potter Moving Image Commission
ACMI Collection
Courtesy the artist and Sullivan + Strumpf, Sydney
results.brief_description:
“The Dark Current has a specific shape to it, that reaches for the essence of a multi-generational experience. One that starts with my mother’s generation, through to mine and on to our children.” Angela Tiatia, 2023

The Dark Current was conceived as a “dream-like visual poem” in three parts that represent the past, present and future. The artwork opens with a striking close-up of a glamorous woman with a pearl in her eye, who is slowly engulfed by water. The artist considers this scene an allegory of the promise that lured her mother’s generation to migrate from the Pacific Islands to countries like New Zealand and Australia in the 1960s.

The middle section weaves together choreographed performances filmed in a production studio with footage of Pacific Island landscapes. It seeks to capture the dark and chaotic feeling of the current moment, as the climate emergency and rising sea levels wreak catastrophic damage across the Pacific Islands and global south.

The final scene is created with software more commonly used to develop videogames. This hyper realistic world is filled with towering ice monuments set atop colourful disco flooring and populated by a cast of performers dressed in pink. The artist describes this joyful vision of the future as “a space of cultural self-actualisation and celebration.”

The Dark Current reflects how we no longer think of the physical and the virtual as being separate spaces, while celebrating Tiatia’s connection to her family history and Sāmoan culture.

Angela Tiatia is a Sāmoan and Australian artist who lives and works in Sydney. She works primarily with moving image and performance to explore contemporary culture, in particular the relationships between representation, gender, neo-colonialism and the commodification of body and place. Tiatia’s work has been exhibited nationally and internationally, and her work is held in private and public collections including Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa; Art Gallery of New South Wales, Sydney; Museum of Contemporary Art, Sydney; National Gallery of Victoria, Melbourne; and Queensland Art Gallery | Gallery of Modern Art, Brisbane.

constellations_primary.name: Pink subversions
constellations_primary.description: Pink dominates Angela Tiatia's The Dark Current. The artist describes this particular colour as “artificial”, “unapologetic” and “pulsating with feminine energy”. In Tiatia's Sāmoan heritage “there is a brashness in the use of colour. I really wanted to embody that.”

results.title: Jedda

results.media_note: Sorry, we don't have images or video for this item.

results.title: Rosalie Kunoth-Monks portrait
results.credit_line: Courtesy the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: Due to Jedda’s popularity and interest in Aboriginal ‘kitsch’ and culture, Arrernte actress Kunoth-Monks and Jedda became entwined. But she never acted again, instead becoming an advocate for Australia’s First Peoples.
results.credit_line_for_label: Courtesy the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia

results.title: House in summer magic lantern slide
results.brief_description: Magic lantern slide with wooden frame. The coloured slide shows a English style house and gardens. Several pencil marking on the wood. On the underside, ‘57’ has been written in a thick white ink.
results.description: Magic lantern slide with wooden frame. The coloured slide shows a English style house and gardens. Several pencil marking on the wood. On the underside, ‘57’ has been written in a thick white ink.

results.title: Magic lantern set effects slide (Man and lions)
results.brief_description: Magic lantern set effects slide with wooden frame. By sliding the effects slide, a man fights between two lions set against a black background. Made by Lawler, 161 Strand, London. ‘91’ written in pencil on wooden frame. Cream tape has been adhered to the edge of the sliding section.

results.title: Magic lantern slipping slide (Knight and Princess)
results.brief_description: Magic lantern set effects slide with dark wooden frame. By sliding the effects slide, a a princess pushes a knight from her window or cuts his climbing rope, resulting in his fall Set against a black background.
results.description: Magic lantern set effects slide with dark wooden frame. By sliding the effects slide, a a princess pushes a knight from her window or cuts his climbing rope, resulting in his fall Set against a black background.

results.title: Magic lantern slipping slide [Boy / Girl]
results.brief_description: Magic lantern set effects slide with dark wooden frame. By sliding the effects slide, a a figure changes from girl features to boy features. Set against a black background. Brown tape adhered to moving slide.
results.description: Magic lantern set effects slide with dark wooden frame. By sliding the effects slide, a a figure changes from girl features to boy features. Set against a black background. Brown tape adhered to moving slide.

results.title: Magic lantern three-panel slipping slide (Flower Bloom)
results.brief_description: Magic lantern set effects slide with wooden frame. The coloured slide shows a flower bud blooming. Two adjustable sliding pieces of glass - slide left and right to show the flower blooming. Set against a black background. Made by W.F. Archer, Liverpool, 43 Lord St and 63 South Castle St. ‘49’ and ‘R’ written in pencil on wooden frame.
